passages.passageHtml:
To go into solitude, a man needs to retire as much from his chamber as from society. I am not solitary whilst I read and write, though nobody is with me. But if a man would be alone, let him look at the stars. The rays that come from those heavenly worlds will separate between him and what he touches. One might think the atmosphere was made transparent with this design, to give man, in the heavenly bodies, the perpetual presence of the sublime. Seen in the streets of cities, how great they are! If the stars should appear one night in a thousand years, how would men believe and adore; and preserve for many generations the remembrance of the city of God which had been shown! But every night come out these envoys of beauty, and light the universe with their admonishing smile. [highlight-1]The stars awaken a certain reverence, because though always present, they are inaccessible; [/highlight-1]but all natural objects make a kindred impression, when the mind is open to their influence. Nature never wears a mean appearance. The flowers, the animals, the mountains, reflected the wisdom of his best hour, as much as they had delighted the simplicity of his childhood.
When we speak of nature in this manner, we have a distinct but most poetical sense in the mind. We mean the integrity of impression made by manifold natural objects. [highlight-2]It is this which distinguishes the stick of timber of the wood-cutter, from the tree of the poet.[/highlight-2] The charming landscape which I saw this morning, is indubitably made up of some twenty or thirty farms. Miller owns this field, Locke that, and Manning the woodland beyond. But none of them owns the landscape. There is a property in the horizon which no man has but he whose eye can integrate all the parts, that is, the poet. This is the best part of these men's farms, yet to this their warranty-deeds give no title.
To speak truly, few adult persons can see nature. Most persons do not see the sun. At least they have a very superficial seeing. [highlight-3]The sun illuminates only the eye of the man, but shines into the eye and the heart of the child.[/highlight-3] The lover of nature is he whose inward and outward senses are still truly adjusted to each other; who has retained the spirit of infancy even into the era of manhood. In the presence of nature, a wild delight runs through the man, in spite of real sorrows. Nature says,—he is my creature, and maugre all his impertinent griefs, he shall be glad with me. [highlight-4]Not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.[/highlight-4]
Crossing a bare common, in snow puddles, at twilight, under a clouded sky, without having in my thoughts any occurrence of special good fortune, I have enjoyed a perfect exhilaration. I am glad to the brink of fear. In the woods too, a man casts off his years, as the snake his slough, and at what period soever of life, is always a child. [highlight-5]In the woods, is perpetual youth.[/highlight-5] Standing on the bare ground,—my head bathed by the blithe air, and uplifted into infinite space,—all mean egotism vanishes. [highlight-6]I become a transparent eye-ball; I am nothing; I see all; the currents of the Universal Being circulate through me; I am part or particle of God.[/highlight-6]
The greatest delight which the fields and woods minister, is the suggestion of an occult relation between man and the vegetable. I am not alone and unacknowledged. They nod to me, and I to them.
[highlight-7]Yet it is certain that the power to produce this delight, does not reside in nature, but in man, or in a harmony of both.[/highlight-7] It is necessary to use these pleasures with great temperance. [highlight-8]Nature always wears the colors of the spirit.[/highlight-8] To a man laboring under calamity, the heat of his own fire hath sadness in it. Then, there is a kind of contempt of the landscape felt by him who has just lost by death a dear friend. [highlight-9]The sky is less grand as it shuts down over less worth in the population.[/highlight-9]

Professor Langley determines quantitatively the effects respectively produced by the radiations from the solar spots, penumbra, and photosphere upon the face of a thermopile, and infers that these effects measure their relative influence on terrestrial climate.
[highlight-1]In thus assuming that the heat communicated to the thermopile measures the solar contribution to terrestrial climate, Professor Langley omits an important factor, viz, the amount of heat absorbed in traversing the earth’s atmosphere;[/highlight-1] and in measuring the relative efficiency of the spots, penumbra, and photosphere, he has not taken into account the variations of diathermancy of the intervening atmospheric matter, which are due to the variations in the source of heat.
[highlight-2]Speaking generally, it may be affirmed that the radiations of obscure heat are more largely absorbed by the gases and vapors of our atmosphere than those of luminous heat,[/highlight-2] and the great differences in the mere luminosity of the spots, penumbra, and photosphere justify the assumption that the radiations of a sun-spot will (to use the expressive simile of Tyndall) lose far more by atmospheric sifting than will those from the photosphere.
[highlight-3]But the spot areas will be none the less effective on terrestrial climate on that account.[/highlight-3] A given amount of heat arrested by the earth’s atmosphere will have even greater climatic efficiency than if received upon its solid surface, inasmuch as the gases are worse radiators than the rocks, and will therefore, cæteris paribus, retain a larger proportion of the heat they receive.
[highlight-4]I have long ago endeavored to show that the depth of the photosphere, from the solar surface inwards, is limited by dissociation;[/highlight-4] that the materials of the Sun within the photosphere exist in a dissociated, elementary condition; that at the photosphere they are, for the most part, combined. This view has since been adopted by many eminent solar physicists, and if correct, demands a much higher temperature within the depths revealed by that withdrawal of the photospheric veil which constitutes a sun-spot.
[highlight-5]If I am right in this, and also in supposing the spot-radiations to be so much more abundantly absorbed than those of the photosphere, and if in spite of this higher temperature of the spots, the surface of the earth receives from them the lower degree of heat measured by Professor Langley, another interesting consequence must follow.[/highlight-5] The excess of spot-heat directly absorbed by the atmosphere, and mainly by the water dissolved or suspended in its upper regions, must be especially effective in dissipating clouds and checking or modifying their formation. The meteorological results of this may be important, and are worthy of careful study.
[highlight-6]In thus venturing to question some of Professor Langley’s inferences I am far from underrating the interest and importance of his researches.[/highlight-6] On the contrary, I regard the quantitative results he has obtained as especially valuable and opportune, in affording means of testing the above-named and other speculations in solar physics. [highlight-7]Similar observations repeated at different elevations would decide, so far as the lower regions are concerned, whether or not there is any difference in the quantity of heat imparted by the bright and obscure portions of the Sun to our atmosphere.[/highlight-7] If the differences already observed by Professor Langley vary in ascending, a new means will be afforded of studying the constitution of the interior of the Sun and its relations to the photosphere. Direct evidence of selective absorption by our atmosphere may thus be obtained, which would go far towards solving one of the crucial solar problems, viz, whether the darker regions are hotter or cooler than the photosphere.
[highlight-8]The obscure radiations from the moon must be absorbed by our atmosphere like those from the sun-spot, and may be sufficiently effective to account for the alleged dissipation of clouds by the full moon.[/highlight-8]
In both cases the climatic influence is greatly heightened by the fact that all the heat thus absorbed is directly effective in raising the temperature of the air. [highlight-9]The action of the absorbed heat in reference to cloud-formation is directly opposite to that of the transmitted solar heat, as this reaching the surface of the earth evaporates the superficial water, and thereby produces the material of clouds.[/highlight-9] On the other hand, the heat which is absorbed by the air increases its vapor-holding capacity, and thus prevents the formation of clouds, or even effects the dissolution of clouds already formed.

A paper was read on March 2, 1882, by Dr. C. W. Siemens at the Royal Society, and he published an article on “A New Theory of the Sun” in the April number of the Nineteenth Century. [highlight-1]All who have read my essay on “The Fuel of the Sun” are surprised at the statement with which the magazine article opens, viz.: that this “may be termed a first attempt to open for the sun a debtor and creditor account, inasmuch as he has hitherto been regarded only as a great almoner pouring forth incessantly his boundless wealth of heat, without receiving any of it back.”[/highlight-1]
[highlight-2]Some of my friends suppose that Dr. Siemens has wilfully ignored the most important element of my theory.[/highlight-2] I am quite satisfied, however, that they are mistaken.[highlight-3]I see plainly enough that although Dr. Siemens quotes my book, he had not read it when he did so.[/highlight-3] This inference has been confirmed by subsequent correspondence with Dr. Siemens, who tells me that he saw the book some years since but had not read it.
In the meantime I will briefly state some of the points of agreement and difference between Dr. Siemens and myself. In the first place, we both take as our fundamental basis of speculation the idea of a universal extension of atmospheric matter, and we both regard this as the recipient of the diffused solar radiations, which are afterwards recovered and recondensed, or concentrated. [highlight-4]Thus our “fuel of the sun” is primarily the same, but, as will presently be seen, our machinery for feeding the solar furnace is essentially different.[/highlight-4]
Certain [highlight-11]desiccated pedants[/highlight-11] have sneered at my title, “The Fuel of the Sun,” as “sensational,” and have refused to read the book on this account; but Dr. Sterry Hunt has provided me with ample revenge. [highlight-5]He has disentombed an interesting paper by Sir Isaac Newton, dated 1675, in which the same sensationalism is perpetrated with very small modification, Sir Isaac Newton’s title being “Solary Fuel.”[/highlight-5]
Dr. Siemens supposes that the rotation of the sun effects a sort of “fan action,” by throwing off heated atmospheric matter from his equatorial regions, which atmospheric matter is afterwards reclaimed and passed over to the polar regions of the sun. This interchange he describes as effected by the differences of pressure on the fluid envelope of the sun. [highlight-6]He maintains that this “centrifugal action, however small in amount as compared with the enormous attraction of the sun, would destroy the balance, and determine a motion towards the sun as regards the mass opposite the polar surface, and into space as regards the equatorial mass.”[/highlight-6] He adds that “the equatorial current so produced, owing to its mighty proportions, would flow outwards into space, to a practically unlimited distance.”
It is evident that if such fan action can bring back all the material that has received the solar radiations, and which holds them either as temperature or otherwise, the restoration and perpetuation of solar energy will be complete, for even the heat received by our earth and its brother and sister planets would still remain in the family, as they would radiate it into the interplanetary atmospheric matter supposed to be reclaimed by the sun.
But, as Mr. Proctor has clearly shown, [highlight-10]the rays of the sun cannot do all the work thus required for his own restoration without becoming extinguished as regards the outside universe; and if the other suns—i.e., the stars—do the same they could not be visible to us.[/highlight-10] [highlight-7]Thus Dr. Siemens’ theory removes our sun from his place among the stars, and renders the great problem of stellar radiation more inscrutable than ever by thus putting the evidence of our great luminary altogether out of court.[/highlight-7]
[highlight-8]My theory, on the contrary, demands only a gradual absorption of solar and stellar rays, such as actual observation of their varying splendor indicates.[/highlight-8] [highlight-9]If space were absolutely transparent, and its infinite depths peopled throughout, the firmament would present to our view one continuous blazing dome, as all the spaces between the nearer stars would be filled by the infinity of radiations from the more distant.[/highlight-9]

What, then, is the rightful limit to the sovereignty of the individual over himself? Where does the authority of society begin? How much of human life should be assigned to individuality, and how much to society?
Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to society, the part which chiefly interests society.
Though society is not founded on a contract, and though no good purpose is answered by inventing a contract in order to deduce social obligations from it, every one who receives the protection of society owes a return for the benefit, and the fact of living in society renders it indispensable that each should be bound to observe a certain line of conduct towards the rest. [highlight-1]This conduct consists, first, in not injuring the interests of one another; or rather certain interests, which, either by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be considered as rights;[/highlight-1] and secondly, in each person's bearing his share (to be fixed on some equitable principle) of the labours and sacrifices incurred for defending the society or its members from injury and molestation. These conditions society is justified in enforcing, at all costs to those who endeavour to withhold fulfilment. Nor is this all that society may do. [highlight-2]The acts of an individual may be hurtful to others, or wanting in due consideration for their welfare, without going the length of violating any of their constituted rights.[/highlight-2] The offender may then be justly punished by opinion, though not by law. As soon as any part of a person's conduct affects prejudicially the interests of others, society has jurisdiction over it, and the question whether the general welfare will or not be promoted by interfering with it, becomes open to discussion. [highlight-3]But there is no room for entertaining any such question when a person's conduct affects the interests of no persons besides himself, or needs not affect them unless they like (all the persons concerned being of full age, and the ordinary amount of understanding).[/highlight-3] In such cases, there should be perfect freedom, legal and social, to do the action and stand the consequences.
[highlight-4]It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have no business with each other's conduct in life, and that they should not concern themselves about the well-doing or well-being of one another, unless their own interest is involved.[/highlight-4] Instead of any diminution, there is need of a great increase of disinterested exertion to promote the good of others. [highlight-5]But disinterested benevolence can find other instruments to persuade people to their good, than whips and scourges, either of the literal sort or in the figurative shape of ridicule or sarcasm.[/highlight-5] The real evil is the want of interest in the good of others. [highlight-6]The doctrine of this essay is, that the individual is sovereign over his own body and mind, and that society has no right to interfere with him, except for the purpose of preventing harm to others.[/highlight-6]
The only part of the conduct of any one, for which he is amenable to society, is that which concerns others. [highlight-7]In the part which merely concerns himself, his independence is, of right, absolute.[/highlight-7] Over himself, over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign. [highlight-8]It is, perhaps, hardly necessary to say that this doctrine is meant to apply only to human beings in the maturity of their faculties.[/highlight-8] We are not speaking of children, or of young persons below the age which the law may fix as that of manhood or womanhood. Those who are still in a state to require being taken care of by others, must be protected against their own actions as well as against external injury. For the same reason, we may leave out of consideration those backward states of society in which the race itself may be considered as in its nonage. [highlight-9]The early difficulties in the way of spontaneous progress are so great, that there is seldom any choice of means for overcoming them; and a ruler full of the spirit of improvement is warranted in the use of any expedients that will attain an end, perhaps otherwise unattainable.[/highlight-9] Despotism is a legitimate mode of government in dealing with barbarians, provided the end be their improvement, and the means justified by actually effecting that end. [highlight-10]Liberty, as a principle, has no application to any state of things anterior to the time when mankind have become capable of being improved by free and equal discussion.[/highlight-10] Until then, there is nothing for them but implicit obedience to an Akbar or a Charlemagne, if they are so fortunate as to find one. [highlight-11]But as soon as mankind have attained the capacity of being guided to their own improvement by conviction or persuasion (a period long since reached in all nations with whom we need here concern ourselves), compulsion, either in the direct form or in that of pains and penalties for non-compliance, is no longer admissible as a means to their own good, and justifiable only for the security of others.[/highlight-11]

Wild animals live by laws as old as the earth itself—laws of instinct, survival, and adaptation that have shaped their existence long before humans walked the plains. In the vast rangelands where the wind sweeps unchecked, creatures such as the wolf, the crow, and the rabbit demonstrate remarkable intelligence and resilience. Yet these same qualities often bring them into conflict with human expansion, leading to stories of both triumph and tragedy.
Consider Lobo, the king of Currumpaw, a wolf whose cunning made him legendary among ranchers in the late nineteenth century. For years, Lobo led his pack with unmatched strategy, avoiding traps and poisons that claimed lesser wolves. [highlight-1]His strength was not merely physical; it was mental.[/highlight-1] He learned the patterns of human behavior, discerning safe paths from dangerous ones, and taught his mates to do the same. [highlight-13]His pack hunted with precision, taking only what they needed while evading detection.[/highlight-13] [highlight-2]But as settlements grew and livestock multiplied, the balance shifted.[/highlight-2] Hunters employed every device—traps, strychnine, and relentless pursuit—to end his reign. In the end, Lobo's downfall came not from weakness but from loyalty: he refused to abandon his captured mate, leading to his capture in 1894. [highlight-3]His story illustrates how wildlife, even at its most intelligent, struggles against relentless human pressure.[/highlight-3]
Similar intelligence appears in less fearsome creatures. Silverspot, an old crow, ruled his band through wisdom gained over many seasons. He knew every inch of his territory—the best roosts, the safest feeding grounds, and the locations of enemies. [highlight-4]Silverspot's calls conveyed complex messages: warnings of hawks, signals for food, or alerts to approaching danger.[/highlight-4] He taught the young crows through example, showing them how to outwit owls and farmers alike. His leadership ensured the flock's survival in a world full of threats. [highlight-14]Yet even such clever birds face risks from habitat loss and indiscriminate shooting, forces that diminish their numbers year by year.[/highlight-14]
Rabbits, too, embody the quiet drama of wildlife survival. Raggylug, a young cottontail, learned early the perils of the open field. His mother trained him in camouflage, stillness, and swift evasion. [highlight-5]When pursued by foxes or hawks, he froze in place, blending with the earth, or dashed in zigzags to confuse his pursuer.[/highlight-5] His world was one of constant vigilance: every rustle might signal death, every shadow a predator. Yet rabbits thrive through sheer reproductive vigor and adaptability, colonizing new thickets when old ones are destroyed. [highlight-6]Their story reminds us that wildlife often persists not through grandeur but through humble persistence.[/highlight-6]
These animals share a common fate in the modern era. Once abundant across prairies, forests, and mountains, many species now dwindle as wilderness gives way to farms, railroads, and cities. The passenger pigeon, once darkening the skies in flocks of millions, vanished entirely within decades due to overhunting and deforestation. [highlight-7]Bison herds that numbered in the tens of millions were reduced to a few hundred by commercial hunting.[/highlight-7] Even songbirds suffer from the drainage of wetlands and the spraying of poisons meant for crops. [highlight-8]The loss is not merely numerical; it disrupts entire ecosystems.[/highlight-8] Predators like wolves control prey populations, preventing overgrazing; birds disperse seeds, aiding forest renewal; [highlight-15]small mammals aerate soil and serve as food for larger creatures.[/highlight-15]
Conservation offers hope. [highlight-9]Thoughtful laws, protected reserves, and public awareness can reverse declines.[/highlight-9] National parks preserve habitats where animals live undisturbed; refuges shield migratory birds; breeding programs restore diminished populations. Success stories exist: the comeback of the American bison from near-extinction shows what deliberate effort can achieve. [highlight-10]Yet protection requires vigilance.[/highlight-10] Poaching, pollution, and climate shifts continue to threaten even guarded species.
Ultimately, wildlife teaches humility. [highlight-11]These creatures do not exist for human amusement or profit; they are fellow inhabitants of a shared planet, each playing a role in nature's intricate web.[/highlight-11] To preserve them is to preserve the balance that sustains us all. [highlight-12]As human activity reshapes the earth, the question remains: will we choose coexistence, or allow the wild chorus to fade into silence? [/highlight-12]

The human mind, that marvelous and mysterious entity, has long fascinated thinkers across centuries. It is the seat of consciousness, the origin of thought, emotion, and will, and the bridge between the material world and our inner experience. [highlight-1]Unlike the body, which we can observe and measure directly, the mind reveals itself only through its operations—perceiving, remembering, reasoning, and feeling.[/highlight-1] Yet these operations are so intimate and constant that we rarely pause to examine their nature.

 [highlight-2]Consider first the stream of consciousness, a term aptly coined to describe the continuous flow of thoughts and sensations that constitute our mental life. [/highlight-2]Our awareness is never static; it moves forward like a river, carrying impressions from the senses, memories from the past, anticipations of the future, and a constant undercurrent of feelings. [highlight-3]Each moment blends into the next, with no sharp divisions.[/highlight-3] What we call the "present" is not a knife-edge instant but a specious present—a short span of duration, perhaps a few seconds, in which we grasp a portion of time as now. [highlight-4]Beyond this lies the remembered past and the imagined future, both of which color the immediate experience.[/highlight-4]

This flowing quality of mind arises from its dependence on the brain, that organ of wondrous complexity. Every mental state has its correlative brain process; no thought occurs without some neural activity. [highlight-5]Injuries to specific brain regions can abolish vision, memory, or speech, demonstrating that the mind is not an independent spirit but intimately bound to physical conditions.[/highlight-5] Yet the mind is more than the sum of these processes. [highlight-6]It selects, attends, and integrates what the brain receives. Attention acts as a spotlight, illuminating certain sensations while dimming others; without it, the flood of sensory input would overwhelm us into chaos.[/highlight-6]

Perception illustrates this integrative power vividly. When we see an object—a tree, say—we do not merely receive patches of color and shape; we perceive a unified thing with meaning. The mind supplies relations: the tree stands apart from the background, has depth, belongs to a category. [highlight-7]This act of perception involves discrimination and association.[/highlight-7] We discriminate qualities—green leaves from brown trunk—and associate them with past experiences: shade, wood, growth. [highlight-8]Association by contiguity links ideas that have occurred together in time or space; similarity connects those resembling each other. These laws govern much of our thinking, from simple recall to creative invention.[/highlight-8]

Memory, too, depends on these principles. It is not a passive storehouse but an active reconstruction. We do not retrieve exact copies of past events; rather, we rebuild them from fragments, guided by cues and interest. [highlight-9]Repetition strengthens paths in the brain, making recall easier; emotion intensifies retention, so vivid joys or sorrows endure longest.[/highlight-9] Yet memory is selective—forgetting serves a purpose by clearing space for the useful and relevant. Without it, the mind would be buried under irrelevant details.

Reasoning builds upon perception and memory. We abstract qualities, form concepts, and draw inferences. From observing many trees, we form the general idea "tree," stripping away particulars to grasp essence. [highlight-10]Judgment follows: we affirm or deny relations between ideas.[/highlight-10] The mind's capacity for abstraction allows science, philosophy, and art; without it, we would remain trapped in the concrete and immediate.

Emotions add color and motive to mental life. Joy, sorrow, fear, anger—these are not mere accidents but adaptive responses. They arise from bodily changes (racing heart in fear, relaxed muscles in contentment) and in turn influence thought and action. [highlight-11]The mind feels these states as its own, weaving them into the stream of consciousness.[/highlight-11]

The self emerges from this rich interplay. We experience a core "I" that persists amid changing thoughts—a sense of personal identity linking yesterday's memories to today's decisions. [highlight-12]This self is not a separate entity lodged in the brain but the unity of the stream itself, felt through bodily sensations (the cephalic stirrings of thought) and emotional tones of ownership.[/highlight-12]

 [highlight-13]Yet the mind's nature remains partly elusive.[/highlight-13] It adapts to environment, learns from experience, and creates novelty. It dreams in sleep, imagines impossibilities, and contemplates its own existence. In moments of reflection, we glimpse its depths: the capacity for wonder, moral insight, and transcendence.  

[highlight-15]In sum, the human mind is a dynamic process—selective, integrative, creative—rooted in biology yet reaching toward meaning and purpose. It is the instrument by which we know the world and ourselves, forever unfolding in the endless stream of conscious life.[/highlight-15]

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering revising the phrase "All who have read my essay" to "Many readers of my essay." Which of the following is the best reason to make this change?

options.A: To make the statement more objective and less exaggerated.
options.B: To emphasize the popularity of the author's essay.
options.C: To clarify that the author is referring to a specific group of people.
options.D: To correct a grammatical error in the original phrasing.

questions.explanationHtml: The word "All" is absolute and can be seen as an exaggeration (hyperbole). Changing it to "Many" makes the claim more measured and less likely to be factually inaccurate. This aligns with a goal of objective writing. Option B is incorrect because "Many" is less emphatic about popularity. Option C is incorrect because both phrases refer to the same general group. Option D is incorrect; there is no grammatical error.

questions.questionHtml: Given that the author's goal in this paragraph is to correct a potential misunderstanding about his view of Dr. Siemens, should this sentence be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it establishes the common but incorrect perception that the author will then correct.
options.B: Kept, because it provides evidence that the author's theory is widely discussed.
options.C: Deleted, because it introduces an unprofessional and gossipy tone to the passage.
options.D: Deleted, because it focuses on the author's friends rather than on the scientific debate.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence serves a clear rhetorical purpose. It presents a misconception ("Some... suppose...") that the author immediately refutes ("I am quite satisfied, however, that they are mistaken."). This structure is effective for clarifying the author's position. Options C and D are incorrect because the sentence is relevant to establishing the author's fair-mindedness. Option B is not the primary purpose.

questions.questionHtml: I see plainly enough that although Dr. Siemens quotes my book, he had not read it when he did so.

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: I have come to suspect that
options.C: It is my belief that
options.D: Evidence confirms that

questions.explanationHtml: The original phrase "I see plainly enough" is based on the author's personal observation. Option D, "Evidence confirms that," is stronger and more professional because it implies the conclusion is based on verifiable proof (which the author then provides in the next sentence). Options B and C are weaker and more speculative than the original.

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering deleting the phrase "as will presently be seen." Should this phrase be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it signals to the reader that a key point of contrast will be developed in the following sentences.
options.B: Kept, because it emphasizes the complexity of the machinery being described.
options.C: Deleted, because it is a wordy and unnecessary interruption in the sentence.
options.D: Deleted, because it makes a promise to the reader that the passage does not fulfill.

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase acts as a transitional guide for the reader. It signals that the author is about to explain the crucial difference ("our machinery") between his theory and Siemens's. This improves the coherence and flow of the argument. The passage does go on to explain the differences, so Options C and D are incorrect. Option B misinterprets the phrase's function.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following alternatives to the underlined word would be LEAST appropriate in this context?

options.A: unearthed
options.B: discovered
options.C: fabricated
options.D: brought to light

questions.explanationHtml: The word "disentombed" is a metaphor meaning "to dig up" or "bring to light." Options A, B, and D all share this general meaning of finding or revealing something. Option C, "fabricated," means "to invent or concoct falsely," which has a completely different and negative meaning that is inappropriate here, as the author is celebrating the discovery of a genuine Newton paper.

questions.questionHtml: The author's primary purpose in including this long, direct quotation from Dr. Siemens is to:

options.A: Provide a concise summary of a complex idea.
options.B: Accurately and fairly represent Siemens's theory before critiquing it.
options.C: Showcase the poetic and descriptive language used by Siemens.
options.D: Highlight a point of agreement between his own theory and Siemens's.

questions.explanationHtml: By quoting Siemens directly, the author ensures he is not misrepresenting the theory he is about to challenge. This is a hallmark of fair and scholarly critique. The quotation is lengthy and detailed, not concise (A), and while descriptive, that's not its main purpose (C). The author will ultimately disagree with Siemens, so highlighting agreement (D) is not the primary goal here.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to add a phrase that clarifies why Dr. Siemens's theory "removes our sun from his place among the stars." Which of the following additions, placed after "stars," would best achieve this?

options.A: , which is an unacceptable outcome for any scientific theory,
options.B: , treating it as a unique case that doesn't follow the same rules as other stars,
options.C: , a concept that has been explored by poets for centuries,
options.D: , by relying on the work of Mr. Proctor,

questions.explanationHtml: The previous sentence explains that if stars operated like Siemens's sun, they would not be visible to us. Therefore, Siemens's theory implies the sun is fundamentally different from other stars. Option B directly states this implication, clarifying the meaning of the metaphor "removes... from his place." The other options do not logically follow from the reasoning presented in the passage.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following choices provides the most effective transition from the previous paragraph?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: In other words,
options.C: For example,
options.D: However,

questions.explanationHtml: The previous paragraph ended with a critique of Siemens's theory (calling it "inscrutable"). The underlined sentence begins "My theory, on the contrary...," which perfectly signals that the author is now presenting his own idea as a direct contrast to the one just criticized. "In other words" (B) would introduce a restatement, not a contrast. "For example" (C) would be illogical. "However" (D) is a weaker contrast word that doesn't explicitly set up the two theories against each other.

questions.questionHtml: The author's main purpose in this sentence is to:

options.A: Describe his own unique observation of the night sky.
options.B: Propose a hypothetical scenario to support his theory that space is not perfectly transparent.
options.C: Argue that the universe is infinite and filled with stars.
options.D: Refute the idea that the firmament appears as a continuous blazing dome.

questions.explanationHtml: This sentence is a "counterfactual" or hypothetical. It describes what the sky would look like ("the firmament would present...") if a certain condition were true ("If space were absolutely transparent..."). Since we do not see a "continuous blazing dome," this hypothetical supports his theory that space is not absolutely transparent and that a "gradual absorption" of rays occurs. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because the sentence is a logical tool, not a description of reality or a direct argument for infinity.

questions.questionHtml: For the sake of the cohesion of this paragraph, the underlined sentence should be:

options.A: placed before the sentence that begins with "But, as Mr. Proctor has clearly shown."
options.B: placed after the sentence that begins with "Thus Dr. Siemens’ theory removes our sun."
options.C: kept where it is now.
options.D: deleted, as it provides information that is irrelevant to the argument about Dr. Siemens.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence is presented as part of Mr. Proctor's reasoning. Logically, the specific point about stars not being visible should come before the conclusion that "Dr. Siemens’ theory removes our sun from his place among the stars." The current placement makes the logical flow awkward. Moving it before the "But..." sentence would build the evidence first, leading to the "Thus..." conclusion more effectively.

questions.questionHtml: The author uses the phrase "desiccated pedants" primarily to:

options.A: express his anger towards those who have personally attacked him.
options.B: characterize his critics in a dismissive and contemptuous way.
options.C: establish a formal and academic tone for the passage.
options.D: introduce a new group of scientists who support his theory.

questions.explanationHtml: "Desiccated" (dried up, withered) and "pedants" (people overly concerned with minor details or rules) is a sharply negative and dismissive characterization of his critics. It shows contempt for their narrow-mindedness in judging his book by its title rather than its content. It does not establish a formal tone (C) and is the opposite of introducing supporters (D). While it expresses a negative feeling, its primary purpose is to characterize and dismiss them, not just to express raw anger (A).

questions.questionHtml: The passage makes which of the following distinctions between Dr. Siemens's theory and the author's own theory?

options.A: Siemens's theory requires a "fan action" for solar restoration, while the author's theory relies on the gradual absorption of rays in space.
options.B: Siemens's theory is based on the work of Sir Isaac Newton, while the author's theory is original.
options.C: Siemens's theory accounts for stellar radiation, while the author's theory focuses only on the sun.
options.D: Siemens's theory has been confirmed by observation, while the author's theory remains a speculation.

questions.explanationHtml: This is a central contrast in the passage. Siemens proposes a "fan action" that reclaims solar material and energy. The author states his own theory "demands only a gradual absorption of solar and stellar rays" (sentence 8). Option B is incorrect because the author uses Newton to defend his title, not as a basis for his theory. Option C is incorrect because the author's theory also addresses stellar rays. Option D is incorrect; the author does not claim his theory is confirmed while Siemens's is not.

questions.questionHtml: The author's primary purpose in citing Sir Isaac Newton's paper "Solary Fuel" is to:

options.A: prove that his own theory is correct.
options.B: demonstrate that the concept of "solar fuel" has historical precedent.
options.C: argue that Newton's theory is superior to Siemens's.
options.D: provide evidence that his critics are ignorant of basic science.

questions.explanationHtml: The author is responding to critics who called his title "sensational." By showing that Newton used a very similar title ("Solary Fuel") over 200 years earlier, he defends his own choice by providing a distinguished historical precedent. It's a rhetorical move to undermine his critics. Option D is a byproduct, but the primary purpose is to legitimize his title through Newton's example.

questions.questionHtml: For the sake of the unity and coherence of the passage, the information in the fourth paragraph (beginning "Dr. Siemens supposes...") could best be described as:

options.A: an unnecessary digression into the details of a flawed theory.
options.B: a fair and necessary explanation of the mechanism behind Siemens's idea.
options.C: a brief summary that could be effectively combined with the third paragraph.
options.D: an emotional appeal that detracts from the author's logical argument.

questions.explanationHtml: Before critiquing a theory, it is essential to explain what that theory is. This paragraph provides a detailed, neutral explanation of the "fan action" mechanism central to Siemens's proposal. This is a necessary step for building a fair and coherent critical argument. While the author disagrees with it, the explanation is not a digression (A) or emotional (D). It is more than a brief summary (C).

questions.questionHtml: Suppose the author had been assigned to write a brief essay evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of a contemporary scientific theory. Would this passage successfully fulfill that assignment?

options.A: Yes, because the author presents both points of agreement and disagreement with Dr. Siemens's theory.
options.B: Yes, because the author provides a detailed biography of Dr. Siemens and his influences.
options.C: No, because the author is primarily concerned with defending his own work from criticism.
options.D: No, because the author fails to identify any weaknesses in Dr. Siemens's theory.

questions.explanationHtml: While the author does engage with Siemens's theory, the passage's primary motivation is highly personal. It begins by discussing how readers of his essay were surprised, and how his friends misunderstood Siemens. The goal is to clarify his own priority and defend his ideas. The essay is not an objective "evaluation" of Siemens's theory; it is a response shaped by the author's personal stake in the matter. Option D is incorrect because the author does identify weaknesses (e.g., the problem with stellar visibility).

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering removing the Highlighted sentence from this paragraph. Should the sentence be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it introduces the main claim that the rest of the paragraph will illustrate.
options.B: Kept, because it provides a necessary transition from the topic of stars to the topic of all natural objects.
options.C: Deleted, because it repeats the idea of the stars' beauty that was established in the previous sentences.
options.D: Deleted, because it interrupts the paragraph's focus on the stars as the primary example of the sublime.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence serves a crucial transitional function. The previous sentences focus exclusively on the stars. This sentence concludes the thought about stars ("The stars awaken...") and then pivots to a broader application ("but all natural objects make a kindred impression"), which the paragraph then explores. Keeping it provides a smooth logical flow.

questions.questionHtml: Given that all of the following are true, which choice provides the most specific and relevant detail to support the essay's claim in this paragraph?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: the raw material of the carpenter, from the muse of the artist.
options.C: a natural resource, from a subject of contemplation.
options.D: a source of fuel, from a symbol of life.

questions.explanationHtml: The paragraph's central idea is the difference between a practical, ownership-based view of nature and an integrated, poetic one. The original wording, "stick of timber of the wood-cutter" versus "tree of the poet," is the most vivid, concrete, and direct illustration of this abstract concept. The other options are more abstract and less impactful than the original's specific imagery.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following choices best maintains the style and tone of the passage while expressing the same idea?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: Adults see the sun, but kids feel it.
options.C: The sun is for adult eyes, but for a child's heart.
options.D: Grown-ups just look at the sun, but children experience it.

questions.explanationHtml: The original sentence has a lyrical, parallel structure ("illuminates only the eye... shines into the eye and the heart") that matches the philosophical and poetic tone of the passage. Options G, H, and J are grammatically weaker, too simplistic, or use informal language ("kids") that clashes with the essay's elevated style.

questions.questionHtml:
The author is considering combining the sentence Not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight. with the previous sentence. Which is the best way to combine them?

The lover of nature is he... who has retained the spirit of infancy even into the era of manhood. In the presence of nature, a wild delight runs through the man, in spite of real sorrows. Nature says,—he is my creature, and maugre all his impertinent griefs, he shall be glad with me. Not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.

options.A: ...glad with me, and not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.
options.B: ...glad with me, for not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.
options.C: ...glad with me, but not the sun or the summer alone, every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.
options.D: ...glad with me, not the sun or the summer alone, but every hour and season yields its tribute of delight.

questions.explanationHtml: The conjunction "for" (meaning "because") creates the most logical connection. The idea that "every hour and season yields its tribute of delight" is the reason or explanation for the previous claim that Nature will make him glad. Option A uses "and," which is a weaker connection. Option C uses "but" incorrectly, and Option D creates a comma splice.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following alternatives would best emphasize the transformative power of nature described in this paragraph?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: The woods are a place of endless youth.
options.C: One finds perpetual youth in the woods.
options.D: In the woods, a man becomes young again.

questions.explanationHtml: The paragraph describes the transformation a person undergoes: "a man casts off his years... is always a child." Option J, "a man becomes young again," directly captures this personal transformation. The other options describe the woods as a location or state, which is accurate, but they don't as actively express the effect on the man that is the focus of the surrounding sentences.

questions.questionHtml: Upon reviewing the essay, the author notices that the sentence I become a transparent eye-ball; I am nothing; I see all; the currents of the Universal Being circulate through me; I am part or particle of God. contains a series of very short, independent clauses. What is the most likely reason the author chose this structure?

options.A: To create a halting, uncertain rhythm that mirrors the speaker's confusion.
options.B: To use a series of powerful, declarative statements that build to a climax of spiritual unity.
options.C: To correct the reader's potential misconception about the speaker's identity.
options.D: To provide a list of clear, step-by-step instructions for achieving a mystical state.

questions.explanationHtml: The structure of short, emphatic clauses creates a rhythmic, incantatory effect. Each phrase is a bold declaration. They build upon one another—from the negation of self ("I am nothing") to the expansion of perception ("I see all") to the final, ultimate claim of unity with the divine. This structure powerfully conveys the climax of the mystical experience.

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering adding the following phrase to the beginning of this sentence: "However, a crucial caveat must be introduced:" Should this phrase be added?

options.A: Yes, because it signals to the reader that the author is about to contradict a previously stated main idea.
options.B: Yes, because the word "Yet" is too informal for this context, and this phrase is more appropriate.
options.C: No, because the sentence already uses the word "Yet" to signal a shift in thought effectively and concisely.
options.D: No, because the sentence describes a harmony, and a "caveat" implies conflict.

questions.explanationHtml: The word "Yet" is a concise and perfectly appropriate transition word that signals a shift or qualification of the previous idea. The paragraph has been describing the delights of nature. "Yet" effectively introduces a counterpoint or nuance. The proposed addition is wordy and redundant, as "Yet" already does the job of introducing a caveat.

questions.questionHtml: The author wants to add a sentence immediately after this one that provides a specific example of this claim. Which choice best accomplishes this goal?

options.A: For instance, a scientist and a poet will see the same flower in very different ways.
options.B: To a man laboring under calamity, the heat of his own fire hath sadness in it.
options.C: The sky is less grand as it shuts down over less worth in the population.
options.D: Therefore, it is necessary to use these pleasures with great temperance.

questions.explanationHtml: The claim "Nature always wears the colors of the spirit" means that a person's internal emotional state (their "spirit") affects how they perceive nature. Option B is a direct and powerful example of this: a man in the grip of "calamity" sees sadness even in his own fire, an element of his home. Option A is a good example of different perspectives but isn't tied to an emotional state. Option C is itself an example, but Option B comes first in the text and is the more immediate illustration of the "spirit" coloring one's immediate environment.

questions.questionHtml: If the author were to delete the Highlighted portion, the sentence would read: "The sky is less grand." How would this deletion affect the passage?

options.A: It would strengthen the sentence by making it more concise and powerful.
options.B: It would weaken the sentence by removing the cause-and-effect relationship that explains the sky's diminished grandeur.
options.C: It would weaken the sentence by shifting the focus from the sky to the people observing it.
options.D: It would strengthen the sentence by removing a vague and subjective phrase.

questions.explanationHtml: The full sentence is not just stating an objective fact ("The sky is less grand"). It is making a philosophical argument that our perception of nature's grandeur is tied to human worth. The Highlighted portion "as it shuts down over less worth in the population" provides the essential reason why the sky is less grand, linking the state of humanity to the experience of the sublime. Deleting it removes this core connection and leaves a bland, unsupported statement.

questions.questionHtml: Which choice most effectively introduces the central criticism the author will develop in the paragraph?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: essentially,
options.C: for example,
options.D: nevertheless,

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase "in thus assuming" directly and clearly sets up the author's critique of Langley's foundational premise. It establishes that Langley's conclusion is flawed because it rests on an incomplete assumption. "Essentially" is vague, "for example" incorrectly suggests Langley's assumption is just one instance of a larger point, and "nevertheless" implies a concession that doesn't fit the context.

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering deleting the underlined sentence. Should the sentence be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it provides a general scientific principle that supports the author's argument about sun-spot radiations.
options.B: Kept, because it introduces a counterargument that the author will later refute.
options.C: Deleted, because it digresses from the main focus on sun-spots and terrestrial climate.
options.D: Deleted, because it merely repeats an idea stated elsewhere in the paragraph.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence establishes a key scientific premise: the atmosphere absorbs obscure (non-luminous) heat more than luminous heat. This premise is crucial because the author will use it to argue that sun-spot radiations (which are less luminous) are absorbed more by the atmosphere. It supports, rather than refutes or digresses from, the main argument.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following true statements, if added here, would provide the best transition between the ideas in the previous sentence and the rest of this paragraph?

options.A: This selective absorption means the spots' direct heating effect on the Earth's surface is diminished.
options.B: The photosphere's radiations are therefore more likely to reach the lower atmosphere unchanged.
options.C: Scientists have long debated the primary causes of climate fluctuation on Earth.
options.D: This is because a gas will retain more of the heat it absorbs than a solid surface will.

questions.explanationHtml: The previous sentences establish that spot-radiation is heavily absorbed by the atmosphere. The sentence beginning "But the spot areas will be none the less effective..." creates a puzzle for the reader. Option D provides the essential "because" statement that resolves the puzzle: absorbed heat is actually more efficient climatically because gases retain heat better than rocks. This logically connects the idea of absorption to the spots' continued effectiveness. Option A would contradict the author's point.

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering changing the phrase "I have long ago endeavored to show" to "Many scientists have shown." Which change would this revision make to the passage?

options.A: It would make the tone more objective and less personal.
options.B: It would emphasize the author's primary role in developing the theory.
options.C: It would correct a misleading statement, as the idea is now widely accepted.
options.D: It would suggest the theory is more recent and less established.

questions.explanationHtml: The original phrasing is very personal ("I have... endeavored to show"). Changing it to "Many scientists have shown" removes the first-person perspective and presents the idea as a more objective, established fact. It shifts the focus from the author's personal claim to the broader scientific consensus mentioned in the next sentence.

questions.questionHtml: The author's main purpose in this sentence is to:

options.A: Present a firm conclusion based on indisputable evidence.
options.B: Summarize the findings of Professor Langley's research.
options.C: Reject an alternative hypothesis about sun-spot temperatures.
options.D: Pose a hypothetical scenario that leads to a new implication.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence is structured as a complex conditional statement beginning with "If I am right in this..." It lays out a series of hypothetical conditions that, if true, would lead to "another interesting consequence." Its purpose is not to state a fact, but to set up a logical framework for a new idea. Options A and B are incorrect because the sentence is conditional, not conclusive or summative.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following alternatives to the underlined portion would NOT be acceptable?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: I in no way mean to underrate
options.C: I am not underrating in the least
options.D: I am far from underrating, regardless of

questions.explanationHtml: The original phrase "far from underrating" is an idiomatic expression meaning "I am not underrating." Options A, B, and C all convey this same meaning clearly and grammatically. Option D, however, creates a grammatical and logical problem. The phrase "regardless of" is typically used to introduce a prepositional phrase (e.g., "regardless of the consequences"). As written, it is a sentence fragment and does not logically connect to the rest of the sentence.

questions.questionHtml: The author wants to add a detail here that specifies what "similar observations" refers to. Which addition would best achieve this purpose?

options.A: Similar observations, using the same type of thermopile,
options.B: Similar observations, conducted at the same time of year,
options.C: Similar observations, focusing on the Moon's radiations,
options.D: Similar observations, measuring the heat from different solar regions,

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase "similar observations" is vague. The reader must infer that it refers to the kind of quantitative measurements of heat from the Sun's "bright and obscure portions" that Professor Langley performed. Option D directly clarifies this by specifying the subject of the observations: "the heat from different solar regions." Options A and B specify the method or timing, not the subject. Option C introduces a new subject (the Moon) not relevant to this sentence.

questions.questionHtml: The author is considering deleting the reference to the moon. If the author's goal is to maintain focus on the central argument about the Sun and sun-spots, should this sentence be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it provides a clear example of the principle of atmospheric absorption.
options.B: Kept, because it connects the main argument to a familiar, observable phenomenon.
options.C: Deleted, because it shifts the focus from the sun to another celestial body.
options.D: Deleted, because it introduces a new and unsupported claim about cloud dissipation.

questions.explanationHtml: While the moon is a different celestial body, its function in this paragraph is to serve as a clear analogy. The author has just finished explaining a complex theory about sun-spots. Introducing the moon provides a familiar, observable example (the "full moon") to illustrate the same principle of "obscure radiations" being absorbed by the atmosphere and affecting clouds. This example directly supports the paragraph's main point about the climatic mechanism of absorbed heat, rather than detracting from it. Deleting it would weaken the logical flow into sentence 9, which explains the principle behind the example.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following versions of the underlined portion is the clearest and most logical?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: as this heat, reaching the surface of the earth,
options.C: as the transmitted solar heat, reaching the surface of the earth,
options.D: as it, reaching the surface of the earth,

questions.explanationHtml: The original sentence uses the pronoun "this," which has a vague antecedent. The reader must infer that "this" refers to "transmitted solar heat." Option C removes all ambiguity by explicitly naming the subject as "the transmitted solar heat." Option B replaces "this" with "this heat," which is an improvement but still slightly less clear than directly naming it. Option D uses "it," which is just as vague as "this.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering adding the following phrase to the beginning of the sentence: "In stark contrast,". Should this phrase be added?

options.A: Yes, because it emphasizes the comparison between the two types of heat.
options.B: Yes, because it signals a shift from the previous paragraph's focus on the moon.
options.C: No, because the idea of opposition is already clear from the word "opposite."
options.D: No, because the phrase is too informal for this scientific context.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence itself already contains the phrase "is directly opposite to," which clearly establishes the contrast between absorbed heat and transmitted solar heat. Adding "In stark contrast" would be redundant and stylistically awkward, as it repeats an idea that is already explicitly stated.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering deleting the phrase "or rather certain interests, which, either by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be considered as rights" from the sentence. Should this phrase be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it clarifies a potentially vague term by defining its basis in law or social agreement.
options.B: Kept, because it introduces the new and separate concept of how laws are created.
options.C: Deleted, because it contradicts the main idea that society is not founded on a contract.
options.D: Deleted, because it unnecessarily repeats the idea of "not injuring the interests of one another."

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase "or rather..." serves a crucial clarifying function. The writer initially uses the broad term "interests," but then immediately refines it to "certain interests" that are considered "rights." The phrase explains the basis for these rights (law or tacit understanding), which strengthens the argument by making the concept more precise and less open to interpretation. It adds necessary detail rather than being repetitive or contradictory.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following alternatives to the underlined portion would be LEAST acceptable?

options.A: lacking proper regard for
options.B: heedless of
options.C: disregarding
options.D: being mindful of

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase "wanting in due consideration" means showing a lack of proper care or thought for the welfare of others. Options A, B, and C all convey a sense of lack or neglect, which aligns with the original meaning. Option D, "being mindful of," means being aware and considerate, which is the direct opposite of the intended meaning.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to add a phrase at the beginning of this sentence to create a logical transition from the previous sentence. Which choice best accomplishes this goal?

options.A: In contrast,
options.B: Furthermore,
options.C: For example,
options.D: In other words,

questions.explanationHtml: The preceding sentence states that society has jurisdiction and the question of interference is open to discussion when conduct does affect others. This sentence begins a discussion of when there is no room for such a question. This is a direct contrast or opposition. "In contrast" effectively signals this shift from one set of circumstances (conduct affects others) to the opposing set (conduct does not affect others).

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering revising this sentence to be more concise. Which of the following versions is the most concise while retaining the original meaning?

options.A: It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference.
options.B: It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine, which is one of selfish indifference, to suppose that human beings have no business with each other's conduct in life.
options.C: A great misunderstanding of this doctrine is to suppose that it advocates for selfish indifference, pretending people should not concern themselves with each other's well-being unless their own interest is involved.
options.D: To suppose this doctrine is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have no business with each other's conduct, would be a great misunderstanding.

questions.explanationHtml: The original sentence is long and contains a slightly confusing "which" clause. Option C streamlines the sentence by turning the definition of "selfish indifference" into a more direct participial phrase ("pretending people should not concern themselves..."). This maintains all the key ideas—the doctrine being misunderstood, the accusation of selfish indifference, and the definition of that indifference—in a clearer and more concise structure. Option A is too concise, as it omits the crucial definition of what "selfish indifference" entails. Options B and D are awkwardly structured.

questions.questionHtml: Which of the following is the best reason for the writer to use the words "whips and scourges" in this sentence?

options.A: To suggest that people in the past were often physically punished for their own good.
options.B: To create a striking and memorable image for coercive and painful forms of persuasion.
options.C: To introduce the main topic of the paragraph, which is the history of physical punishment.
options.D: To argue that figurative punishments like ridicule are worse than physical ones.

questions.explanationHtml: "Whips and scourges" are powerful, visceral images associated with punishment and force. The author uses them metaphorically to represent any kind of coercive, painful pressure—whether physical or social (like "ridicule or sarcasm"). The purpose is to create a stark contrast with the "other instruments" of "disinterested benevolence," making the argument more vivid and emphatic. The paragraph's main topic is not the history of punishment (C), nor does it compare the severity of physical vs. figurative punishment (D).

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to emphasize the core principle of the essay in this sentence. Which placement of the phrase "and this is the essential point" would best achieve this goal?

options.A: (as it is now) The doctrine of this essay is, that the individual is sovereign...
options.B: The doctrine of this essay is that the individual is sovereign over his own body and mind, and, this is the essential point, that society has no right to interfere with him...
options.C: The doctrine of this essay is that the individual is sovereign over his own body and mind, and that society has no right to interfere with him, except for the purpose of preventing harm to others—and this is the essential point.
options.D: The doctrine of this essay is—and this is the essential point—that the individual is sovereign over his own body and mind, and that society has no right to interfere with him, except for the purpose of preventing harm to others.

questions.explanationHtml: By placing the interrupting phrase "and this is the essential point" right after the introductory clause "The doctrine of this essay is," the writer signals to the reader that the entire following statement is the crucial idea. This framing emphasizes the totality of the principle—both the individual's sovereignty and the sole justification for societal interference—as the one key takeaway. The other placements awkwardly emphasize only a portion of the idea.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering revising this sentence. Which revision best combines clarity with a tone appropriate for this philosophical essay?

options.A: In the part which merely concerns himself, his independence is absolute as a matter of right.
options.B: Regarding his own business, a man's got total independence, right?
options.C: In his own private affairs, his independence is, like, totally absolute.
options.D: Independence is his, in the part self-concerning, of right absolute.

questions.explanationHtml: The original sentence is clear but slightly formal. Option A maintains the formal, academic tone of the essay while rearranging the phrase "of right" to the slightly more fluid "as a matter of right." Option B uses a colloquial tone ("a man's got," "right?") that is inappropriate for the passage. Option C uses informal filler ("like"). Option D uses an awkward, archaic sentence structure that hinders clarity.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to signal to the reader that an important qualification or exception to the main argument is about to be introduced. Which word or phrase best serves this purpose?

options.A: Therefore,
options.B: However,
options.C: In conclusion,
options.D: Specifically,

questions.explanationHtml: The preceding paragraphs have established the broad principle of individual sovereignty. This sentence introduces a crucial limitation: the principle does not apply to children or those not in "the maturity of their faculties." This is a direct exception to or qualification of the previously stated general rule. "However" is the ideal transition word to signal this shift from the general principle to its specific limits.

questions.questionHtml: Which choice provides the most logical and specific transition between the two independent clauses in this sentence?

options.A: NO CHANGE (; and a ruler full of the spirit...)
options.B: ; consequently, a ruler full of the spirit...
options.C: ; for example, a ruler full of the spirit...
options.D: ; in contrast, a ruler full of the spirit...

questions.explanationHtml: The first clause establishes a premise: the difficulties are so great that there is "seldom any choice of means." The second clause states a conclusion or direct result that follows from this premise: a progressive ruler is therefore justified in using "any expedients." "Consequently" perfectly expresses this cause-and-effect relationship. "And" is too weak, "for example" is inaccurate (the ruler's actions are not an example of the difficulties), and "in contrast" suggests an opposition that doesn't exist.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering deleting the phrase "as a principle" from the sentence. Should this phrase be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it emphasizes that the author is discussing the abstract concept, not just the word "liberty."
options.B: Kept, because it is grammatically necessary to complete the sentence.
options.C: Deleted, because it adds nothing to the meaning and only makes the sentence wordier.
options.D: Deleted, because it contradicts the idea that liberty can be applied in some situations.

questions.explanationHtml: The phrase "as a principle" is meaningful. It distinguishes the abstract, philosophical concept of liberty from the practical experience of it. The author's point is that the philosophical principle doesn't apply to "backward states of society." Removing the phrase would make the statement more absolute ("Liberty has no application..."), which is slightly less precise than the author's nuanced claim about its status as a guiding rule.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering moving the parenthetical phrase "(a period long since reached in all nations with whom we need here concern ourselves)" to the end of the sentence. Should the phrase be kept in its original position or moved?

options.A: Kept in its original position, because it immediately clarifies which "mankind" the author is referring to.
options.B: Kept in its original position, because it explains why the author believes in absolute liberty for all.
options.C: Moved to the end, because it is an unimportant aside that disrupts the main point about compulsion.
options.D: Moved to the end, because it would create a more powerful and dramatic conclusion to the sentence.

questions.explanationHtml: The parenthesis is placed directly after the condition ("as soon as mankind have attained the capacity...") to immediately qualify it. The author is saying, in effect, "once this condition is met—and for our purposes, it already has been—then compulsion is no longer admissible." Keeping the phrase in its original position provides an instant clarification, assuring the reader that the subsequent conclusion about compulsion applies to the societies the essay is concerned with. Moving it to the end would create ambiguity and weaken the logical flow.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering deleting the underlined sentence. Should the sentence be kept or deleted?

options.A: Kept, because it provides a specific example of Lobo's physical prowess.
options.B: Kept, because it introduces the main idea of the paragraph, which the following sentences develop.
options.C: Deleted, because it repeats information already stated in the previous sentence.
options.D: Deleted, because it contradicts the later point about Lobo's loyalty leading to his downfall.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence "His strength was not merely physical; it was mental" acts as a topic sentence for the paragraph. It transitions from the general idea of his legendary cunning to the specific details that follow, which explain his mental abilities (learning human patterns, teaching his pack). Therefore, it is essential to keep it.

questions.questionHtml: Which choice most effectively establishes the change in circumstances described in the rest of the paragraph?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: In fact, as settlements grew and livestock multiplied, the balance shifted.
options.C: For example, as settlements grew and livestock multiplied, the balance shifted.
options.D: Previously, as settlements grew and livestock multiplied, the balance shifted.

questions.explanationHtml: The word "But" correctly signals a contrast between Lobo's previous successful evasion and the new, challenging circumstances brought by human expansion. The other options do not fit the context: "In fact" would emphasize a previous point, "For example" would introduce an illustration of a point, and "Previously" would indicate a time before the events being described, which is the opposite of the intended meaning.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to add a detail here that specifies the method of Lobo's capture mentioned in the previous sentence. Which choice best accomplishes this goal?

options.A: The hunters used a clever trap near his den.
options.B: His loyalty was exploited by hunters who used his captured mate as bait.
options.C: The relentless human pressure was too much for him to overcome.
options.D: He was finally caught after a long chase across the Currumpaw region.

questions.explanationHtml: The previous sentence states that Lobo's downfall came from refusing to abandon his captured mate. To specify the method of capture, the writer should explain how that loyalty was used against him. Option B directly states that hunters used the captured mate as bait, which is the specific method of capture that exploited his loyalty.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering revising the underlined phrase to "signals for food and alerts to approaching danger." Should the writer make this revision?

options.A: Yes, because the original phrasing is unnecessarily repetitive.
options.B: Yes, because a colon should only be used to introduce a list of two or more items.
options.C: No, because the original phrasing correctly emphasizes the variety of messages through the use of "or."
options.D: No, because the colon should be followed by a complete sentence.

questions.explanationHtml: The original phrasing with "or" effectively communicates that Silverspot's calls were not just a set list, but could convey any one of these complex message types depending on the situation. The revision using "and" would make the list seem like a single, combined message rather than distinct possibilities. The colon is correctly used to introduce the list of examples.

questions.questionHtml: Which choice provides the most logical and specific detail at this point in the essay?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: he would try to find a safe place to hide.
options.C: he relied on the skills his mother taught him.
options.D: he knew that survival was not guaranteed.

questions.explanationHtml: This paragraph is specifically about the tactics Raggylug learned for survival. The original sentence provides concrete, vivid examples of those tactics ("froze in place," "dashed in zigzags"). The other options are too vague (B, C) or are a general statement of fact (D) that doesn't illustrate the specific skills mentioned in the topic sentence.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to link the idea in this sentence back to the examples of Lobo and Silverspot. Which choice best achieves that link?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: Unlike the more famous Lobo, their story reminds us...
options.C: Therefore, their story, unlike that of the passenger pigeon, reminds us...
options.D: Their story, much like those of Lobo and Silverspot, reminds us...

questions.explanationHtml: The essay has presented Lobo and Silverspot as examples of intelligence and resilience in the face of human pressure. The point about rabbits persisting through "humble persistence" is intended to be a parallel example of wildlife survival, not a contrast. Option D correctly connects the rabbit's story to the previous animal stories, showing they all offer a similar lesson.

questions.questionHtml: The writer is considering adding the following true statement after this sentence: "This drastic reduction forever changed the ecology of the Great Plains." Should the writer make this addition?

options.A: Yes, because it provides a necessary transition to the next sentence's focus on the passenger pigeon.
options.B: Yes, because it elaborates on the ecological consequence mentioned later in the paragraph.
options.C: No, because the information is not directly relevant to the paragraph's focus on numerical loss.
options.D: No, because it interrupts the paragraph's progression from specific examples to a general statement.

questions.explanationHtml: The very next sentence after the proposed addition is: "The loss is not merely numerical; it disrupts entire ecosystems." The proposed sentence about the changed ecology of the Great Plains provides a perfect, specific example of that general principle. It directly elaborates on the idea of ecological disruption that is central to the paragraph's argument.

questions.questionHtml: For the sake of the logic and coherence of this paragraph, this sentence should be placed:

options.A: where it is now.
options.B: before the sentence about the passenger pigeon.
options.C: before the sentence about songbirds.
options.D: at the beginning of the paragraph.

questions.explanationHtml: The paragraph first gives specific, numerical examples of loss (passenger pigeon, bison, songbirds). After presenting these examples, it then provides a general statement that analyzes the deeper, more significant consequence of those numerical losses: the disruption of ecosystems. The sentence is logically placed after the examples to serve as a concluding thought and transition to explaining how ecosystems are disrupted.

questions.questionHtml: Which choice best maintains the tone and style of the passage?

options.A: NO CHANGE
options.B: A bunch of good rules, safe zones, and people knowing stuff can fix things.
options.C: Legislative action, conservation areas, and citizen education are potential solutions.
options.D: We can turn this around if we just make some laws and tell people about it.

questions.explanationHtml: The passage maintains a formal, informative, and slightly literary tone. "Thoughtful laws, protected reserves, and public awareness" fits this tone perfectly. Option C is also formal, but "potential solutions" is slightly more hesitant than "can reverse declines," which is a stronger and more hopeful statement consistent with the paragraph's message. Options B and D are too informal and colloquial for the passage's style.

questions.questionHtml: The writer wants to add a sentence after this one that best supports it. Which choice does that?

options.A: National parks are a cornerstone of modern conservation efforts.
options.B: The comeback of the American bison is a testament to successful intervention.
options.C: For instance, poachers continue to target elephants and rhinos even in protected reserves.
options.D: Breeding programs have been instrumental in restoring populations of endangered species.

questions.explanationHtml: The sentence "Yet protection requires vigilance" means that even when protection is in place, one must be constantly watchful because threats persist. Option C provides a direct example of this by stating that poaching (a threat) continues even in protected reserves, illustrating exactly why vigilance is required. The other options are positive examples of successful protection, which don't directly support the need for vigilance.
